plea.details: Richard Fanne Gildert, along with John Ingledesby, Walter Fetplace, and Michael Luke, is accused of falsely and maliciously procuring an indictment against John Patyn (also known as John Payn), Gabriel Fleming (also known as Gabriel Flomyng), and Robert Basset. The indictment, taken on January 20, 34 Henry VI at Hillingdon, Middlesex, before Justices of the Peace, falsely accused them of assaulting Walter John with force and arms (swords, staves, bows and arrows, lances, langdebeves, jacks, sallets, briganders, and other defensive weapons) against the King's peace. John Patyn was residing in London at the time of the indictment, not Middlesex. This action is brought under a statute of 8 Henry VI, which allows those falsely indicted and acquitted to recover triple damages from the procurers.
procedural_notes: Defendant was attached to answer.

plea.details: The defendants, Thomas Hawe, John Hawe, and Alan Hore, arrayed in a warlike manner with swords, staves, cloaks, jacks, saddles, lances, and bills of war, forcibly entered and held four acres of land, meadow, and pasture belonging to Thomas Greswold. Thomas Greswold and his predecessors had been peacefully seised of this land for 200 years or more. They also drained a pond, evacuating the water and fish (20 lampreys, 20 bream, 20 tench, and 200 roach) valued at 100 shillings, and cut a bolt from a pipe worth twenty pence, taking it. Furthermore, they assaulted Thomas Greswold, a King's peacekeeper and justice, in his house while he was dining with Lady Isabella Merrell and other women, shooting arrows at him and causing great fear.
procedural_notes: The King caused the indictment against the defendants for these actions to come before him for determination.
A writ was issued to the sheriff to ensure the defendants appeared to answer.

Alan Hore presented royal letters patent, dated 30 January in the 34th year of the King's reign, by which the King, of his special grace, pardoned and released Alan for all trespasses, contempts, and offenses committed before 9 July in the 33rd year of the King's reign.
Based on the pardon, Alan Hore requested to be dismissed by the court.
It was considered by the court that Alan Hore should be dismissed without a day.

plea.details: Insurrection and levying war against the King, arrayed in warlike manner with swords, staves, daggers, bows, arrows, lances, shields, helmets, brigandines, cuirasses, gorgets, steel caps, and other defensive arms, aiding Thomas Courtenay Earl of Devon to support the Duke of York.

plea.details: A dispute over twenty acres of land (viginti acris terre). Richard Everard claims Richard Frank unjustly disseised him of the land. Richard Frank, and his servant John Frank, claim lawful re-entry based on a prior grant of the land from Stephen (who was seised in fee) to Richard Frank, and a complex chain of inheritance and grants involving John Frank (son and heir of Stephen), Thomas Frank, and Joanna (who later married Richard Everard).
procedural_notes: A jury was summoned to appear before the King (coram domino Rege) to inquire into the matter.
The case was halted (remansit sine die) due to the death of King Edward IV (dominus Edwardus nuper Rex Anglie quartus).

After the King's death, the case resumed under the new King (Regis nunc). Richard Everard, through his attorney, requested a new writ (breve) to be directed to the sheriff of Somerset for summoning a new jury (venire faciendo xxiiij).

The trench also severely impeded the King's lieges' travel on the highway.

plea.details: Defendants, along with other unknown wrongdoers, incited and abetted by Thomas Hawe, forcibly entered and held 4 acres of land, meadow, and pasture belonging to Thomas Greswold, against the statute concerning forcible entries. Armed with swords, staves, bows, arrows, axes, helmets, sallets, lances, and bills of war, they also removed Greswold's drainpipe, emptied his pond of water and fish (20 pike, 20 bream, 20 tench, and 200 roach, valued at 100 shillings), cut and stole the pipe's valve (valued at 20 pence). They then proceeded to Greswold's house, a Justice of the Peace, and assaulted him while he was at supper. Despite Greswold identifying himself as a JP and ordering them to keep the peace, they assaulted him again, shooting many arrows and causing a great and terrible affray.
procedural_notes: Indictment was presented on Thursday, St. Bartholomew's Day, in the 30th regnal year of the King, at Kenilworth, before John Brown and other Justices of the Peace.
The King caused the indictment to be brought before him for determination.
A writ was issued to the sheriff to bring the defendants to answer.
On the Octave of St. Hilary, Alan Hore appeared in person at Westminster.

plea.details: Felony and robbery. The defendants feloniously took and carried away four silver belts bound with a seal in bags, valued at 20 shillings, belonging to John Wale at Spotton, Northamptonshire, on Thursday, August 16, 1459, around 5 AM.
procedural_notes: Defendants were attached by their bodies by the Marshal.
Plaintiff John Wale appointed pledges for prosecution: Clement of St Clement Danes, London (Middlesex), gentleman, and Henry Honey of Southwark (Surrey), yeoman.
Defendants pleaded not guilty and put themselves upon the country (requested a jury trial).

Bail was granted to the defendants by John Dyve of Harleston (Northamptonshire), gentleman; William Ashby of Abthorpe (Northamptonshire), gentleman; John Catesby of Harleston (Northamptonshire), gentleman; and John Frank of Harleston (Northamptonshire), gentleman.
The case remained without day due to King Edward IV's usurpation of the throne from Henry VI.
Plaintiff John Wale failed to appear on the fourth day of the plea, resulting in him and his pledges being held in mercy. Defendants were discharged from John Wale's private suit.
Defendants were subsequently re-charged and interrogated at the suit of the King for the same felony and robbery.
Defendants again pleaded not guilty and put themselves upon the country (requested a jury trial).

Further bail was granted to the defendants by John Horne of Banastre (Northamptonshire), gentleman; William Ashby of Abthorpe (Northamptonshire), gentleman; and John Bretayn of Harleston (Northamptonshire), gentleman.
A writ was issued to the sheriff for the next appearance.

plea.details: The defendants forcibly entered John Wale's land in Sproxton, constructed and compelled a granary, and took four cartloads of rye/grain (valued at 20 shillings) feloniously. They detained the grain by force in Brikelesworth. They prevented Thomas Shyreff, a King's bailiff, from replevying the grain at John Wale's suit, threatening him. Later, when the undersheriff Robert Ense attempted to replevy the grain, the defendants, before his arrival, threshed the grain at night and feloniously carried, embezzled, and removed it outside the county limits. These actions were against the form of the statute concerning illicit conventicles, riots, routes, and insurrections, as well as against the King's peace and statutes concerning replevin, causing John Wale 40 pounds in damages.

plea.details: Simon Lodbroke was convicted by a jury for publishing a bond of 800 pounds debt owed to John Plumer, citizen and merchant of London. He was subsequently exacted to outlawry and later surrendered himself to the King's Marshalsea prison to satisfy the King for his redemption.
procedural_notes: An order was issued in the 36th year of the King's reign to exact Simon Lodbroke until he should be outlawed.

At the hustings court of common pleas held in London on the Monday after the feast of St. Matthew the Apostle in the 37th year of the King's reign, and at four subsequent hustings, Simon was exacted but did not appear.
Simon Lodbroke was outlawed for non-appearance.

On the 29th day of January in the same term, Simon Lodbroke appeared in person before the King at Westminster and surrendered himself to the King's Marshalsea prison on account of the outlawry, and was committed to the Marshal.

plea.details: feloniously and against the King's peace with a drawn knife from premeditated malice made an assault upon John Tyler and then and there with the said knife struck the said John Tyler to the heart and feloniously killed and murdered him against the King's peace
procedural_notes: The indictment was presented by twelve jurors at Winchester before Justices of the Peace Michael Skillyng and his associates.
The King later caused this indictment to come before him at Westminster to be terminated.
Roger Halle surrendered himself to the King's Marshalsea prison at Westminster.

The King, by his letters patent dated 1st March in the 38th year of his reign, of his special grace, pardoned, remitted, and released Roger Halle from the suit of his peace for the aforesaid felonies and murders, and all other felonies, murders, trespasses, and offenses committed before 20th November in the 38th year of the King's reign.
Roger Halle also produced a sealed writ from the King directed to his justices.

plea.details: Complaint of contempt and trespass against the form of a statute regarding makers of false deeds. John Guerley is accused of fabricating and publishing diverse false deeds and documents concerning a messuage with a garden belonging to John Godyn and Christiana, thereby disturbing their possession and title. The action is brought by Godyn and his wife, qui tam (as much for the King as for themselves), acknowledging that the statute prescribes a fine and redemption for the King upon conviction.
procedural_notes: Pledges for prosecution: William Aleyn and Roland Swayn.

plea.details: For damages sustained by John Hale due to a trespass committed by Edmund Blake with force and arms against the King's peace, for which Edmund was convicted.
procedural_notes: A writ (sicut pluries) was issued to the sheriff to levy 150 pounds from Edmund Blake's lands and chattels to be rendered to John Hale.

The sheriff returned that he seized goods and chattels of Edmund Blake worth 40 marks, which remain unsold due to lack of buyers, and that Edmund has no further assets (goods, chattels, lands, or tenements) from which more money can be made.

Therefore, the sheriff is ordered to sell the previously seized goods and chattels (worth 40 marks) and to levy the remaining 106 pounds, 13 shillings, and 4 pence from Edmund Blake's lands and chattels.

plea.details: John Manyngham with force and arms took, imprisoned, and ill-treated Simon Rogger at Herdwyk, detaining him in prison against the law for three days, and took and carried away his goods and chattels (five saddles and five bridles) found there, to Simon's grave damage and against the King's peace. Simon initially claimed 100 marks in damages.
procedural_notes: Defendant pleaded that Simon Rogger was his villein, appurtenant to his manor of Putokeshardewyk, and thus should not be permitted to respond to the writ.
Plaintiff replied that he was a free man and of free condition, not the defendant's villein.
The case remained without a day (sine die) due to the change of reign, as King Edward IV succeeded King Henry VI.
Plaintiff later obtained a writ of resummons for the defendant and a venire facias to bring a jury.
At the Nisi Prius hearing before Justices Peter Ardern and Thomas Billyng, the jury found that Simon Rogger was a free man.
Damages for Simon Rogger were assessed at 40 shillings.
Judgment was for Simon Rogger, and the defendant John Manyngham was to be arrested (capiatur).

plea.details: The new foundation, erection, and continued maintenance of a 'hamme' (weir/sluice) with a 'gurgite' (weir/fish-garth) in the River Thames near Rotecote bridge in Faringdon. This structure obstructs the river, causing excessive water levels and flooding of the royal highway from Faringdon to Rotecote, and inundating lands, meadows, and pastures belonging to the Abbot of Beaulieu Regis in Faringdon, and lands in Eton and Buscote, and other free tenants adjacent to the river. This has led to damage, danger, and loss of property for royal subjects traversing the highway, and diminished profits for landowners. It also significantly hinders the common passage of the King's lieges by boat, contrary to statute and to the contempt of the King and nuisance of the whole country.
procedural_notes: Presented on October 11, 21 Henry VI, at Whediche, before Peter Fetiplace, sheriff of Berks, by the oath of twelve jurors.
The King caused the presentment to be brought before him for determination.
Defendant, William Warbelton, appeared by his attorney.

Defendant claimed that in Berkshire, near Rotecote bridge, there are two towns, Chepyngfaryngdon and Lytelfaryngdon, but no known town, hamlet, or place called 'Faryngdon' without an addition, as alleged in the presentment.
William Crexton, prosecuting for the King, asserted that a town known as 'Faryngdon' exists without addition.
Issue was joined, and a jury is to inquire before the King in 15 days from Easter, wherever he may be.

procedural_notes: The sheriff was ordered to distrain Sextil, formerly sheriff of the county, to bring the bodies of Richard Hadilsey and John Whiting, whom he had arrested and detained in the King's prison under his custody, before the King on this day (Octave of Hilary) to answer for various trespasses, contempts, insurrections, and forcible entries for which they were indicted.
The defendants did not appear.
The sheriff returned that he was distrained, and his issues and pledges (Richard Bro and Nicholas Bro) are in mercy.
The sheriff was re-ordered to distrain Sextil and to bring the bodies of Richard Hadilsey and others before the King on the quindene of Easter.

plea.details: for redemption on account of a certain trespass against William May, committed with force and arms and against the peace of the King, concerning which John Crofford was convicted by a jury of the country.
procedural_notes: The sheriff was commanded to distrain Roger Chamberleyn, knight, formerly sheriff of the aforesaid county, by all lands and issues, so that he should have the body of John Crofford, lately of Freston, groom, captured by him and detained in the King's prison under his custody, as shown by his return sent previously before the King, to appear before the King on this day (the Octave of St. Hilary) to satisfy the King concerning the redemption.
He (John Crofford) did not come, and the sheriff returned that he (Roger Chamberleyn) was distrained, wherefrom issues are due; his mainpernors (John Baron and William Baron) are in mercy.
Therefore, the sheriff is commanded to distrain him (Roger Chamberleyn) by all lands and issues, so that he should have the body of the aforesaid John before the King on the quindene of Easter.

plea.details: contempt and trespass
procedural_notes: It was commanded to the sheriff that he should not omit, etc., but distrain Miles Stapleton of Ingham in the aforesaid county, Esquire, late sheriff of the aforesaid county, by all his lands, etc., and that concerning the issues, etc., and that he should have his body before the Lord King on this day, namely in the Octave of Saint Hilary, wherever, etc., to answer the Lord King concerning a plea of contempt and trespass.
And he did not come.
And the sheriff returned that he was distrained, whence issues [are lost] and mainpernors by Richard Norton and David V. They (the mainpernors) are in mercy.

And previously it was commanded to the sheriff that he should not omit, etc., but distrain him by all his lands, etc., and that concerning the issues, etc., and that he should have his body before the Lord King fifteen days from Easter wherever, etc.

plea.details: For certain trespasses, contempts, and forcible entries made.
procedural_notes: Command to the sheriff to distrain Robert Wood and William Wyllys to answer the King on the Octaves of St. Hilary.
Defendants did not appear.
Sheriff returned Robert Wood distrained, issues 10d. His pledges, Richard Marter and John Heerde, were in mercy (fined).
Sheriff returned William Wyllys distrained, issues 10d. His pledges, Richard Hert and David V?, were in mercy (fined).
Alias distringas issued for defendants to appear before the King fifteen days from Easter.

plea.details: John Glyn sues William Maryner for twenty marks which he owes and unjustly detains, based on an obligatory bond executed on August 14, 36 Henry VI. William claims the bond was made under duress of imprisonment by John Glyn at Bere Ferrers in Devon. John replies that William was free and willingly executed the bond.
procedural_notes: Pledges for the plaintiff were Hugh Fenne and Henry Dene.
Defendant was granted license to imparl.
A jury was ordered to appear before the King at Westminster.
The case remained 'sine die' (without a day) due to the accession of King Edward IV, legitimately removing King Henry VI from power.
On June 11, 1 Edward IV, John Glyn sought and was granted a writ to the sheriff of Devon to resummon William and summon a jury.

plea.details: for various trespasses, contempts, and forcible entries
procedural_notes: Precept issued to the sheriffs of London to arrest defendants by their bodies.
Defendants summoned to answer the King.
Defendants did not appear.

Order issued to exact defendants from county to county until outlawed.
Defendants to be taken and produced before the King fifteen days from Easter.
Writ delivered in court to John Bele, deputy of Robert, for execution.

plea.details: Because the aforesaid Manricus for suspicion of felony did not duly appear in the court of the present Lord King before the King himself on a certain day fixed for him, as his aforesaid pledges pledged him, and they did not come.
procedural_notes: It was commanded to the sheriffs that they cause to be exacted Manricus Mongomery, John Coke, Edward Godrych, and John Simond from husting to husting until they are outlawed, if not, etc. And then they are to take them safely, etc. so that they may have their bodies before the Lord King on this day, namely in the Octave of Saint Hilary, wherever, etc. to satisfy the Lord King for his redemption.

And the sheriffs did not send a writ thereof. Therefore, it is commanded to the sheriffs that they cause them anew to be exacted from husting to husting until, etc. they are outlawed if not, etc. And then they are to take them safely, etc. so that they may have their bodies before the Lord King in the Octave of Saint Martin, wherever, etc.

plea.details: Jury empanelled between the King (represented by Thomas Crexton) and John Talmache to determine if Talmache enfeoffed Richard Doket and Roger Rokwood of the manor of Bentley and Codenham in Suffolk, as alleged by an inquisition taken before Henry Tudenham, the King's escheator, and returned into Chancery.
procedural_notes: Case put in respite until 15 days from Easter due to lack of jurors.

Defendants failed to appear and sheriff failed to return writ.

plea.details: for not prosecuting his writ of appeal against William Clyk, formerly of Trelonthes Magna in the parish of St. Probus, Cornwall, gentleman, otherwise known as William Tomkyn of Trelonthes aforesaid, Cornwall, yeoman, concerning the ravishment of Joan, wife of the aforesaid John, and for breaking the peace of the present King.
procedural_notes: Order to the sheriff that he cause John Basse to be exacted from county to county until he is outlawed if he does not appear; then, he is to capture him and safely keep him so that he may have his body before the King on this day, namely in the Octave of St. Hilary, wherever the King may be.

plea.details: Assault, battery, wounding, imprisonment, ill-treatment, and taking of a purse with 40 shillings.
procedural_notes: Defendant (John Steven) did not appear.

A writ of Exigent was ordered to cause him to be exacted from county to county until outlawed.
The defendant's body was ordered to be brought before the King on the Octave of Saint John the Baptist.
A new day (dies datus) was given to the plaintiff's attorney on the Octave of Saint Hilary due to the defendant's non-appearance.

procedural_notes: Sheriff returned defendants not found
Order for exigent leading to outlawry

plea.details: Defendants by force and arms broke John's enclosure at Shaston, made an assault on John there, beat, wounded, and ill-treated him, and trampled and consumed his grass growing there, to the value of 100 shillings.
procedural_notes: Writ of capias (sicut pluries) was issued to the sheriff to arrest the defendants.
The sheriff returned that the defendants were not found.
Therefore, the sheriff is ordered to exact them from county to county until they are outlawed if they do not appear.
If found, the sheriff is to have their bodies before the King in the Octave of Saint John the Baptist.
The previous return was in the Octave of Saint Hilary.

plea.details: Jury found that Simon Roger was a free man and not a villain belonging to John Manyngham's manor, as Simon had alleged, and assessed damages for the transgression.
procedural_notes: A jury was summoned to recognize the truth of the matter.
The process was continued before the King.
Justices of Assize returned the jury's verdict.
Simon recovered forty shillings in damages and costs.
John was ordered to be arrested (capiatur).
Simon acknowledged full satisfaction of the damages on 10 November, 3 Edward IV.
John Manyngham was subsequently acquitted.

plea.details: On January 1st, 39th year of the present King's reign, the defendant assaulted the plaintiff with force and arms (swords, staves, etc.) at Westminster, causing 100 shillings damage.
procedural_notes: Pledges for prosecution: Adam Hay and Simon Braybrook.
Initial writ ordered the sheriff to attach the defendant to appear at Westminster on the Saturday after the Purification of Blessed Mary.
Sheriff returned that the defendant had no property (nichil habet).
Second writ (capias) ordered the sheriff to arrest the defendant and bring his body to Westminster on the Monday after the Purification of Blessed Mary.
Sheriff returned that the defendant was not found (non est inventus).
It was testified on behalf of the plaintiff that the defendant is lurking and running in Bedfordshire.
Third writ (alias capias) ordered the sheriff to arrest the defendant in Bedfordshire and bring his body to Westminster on the Saturday after the quindene of Easter.

plea.details: Concerning the taking and carrying away of two walls, which the defendants claim was done by license from John Gote. The Crown, through its prosecutor, denies that John Gote granted such a license.
procedural_notes: Jury to be summoned from Middlesex and London to inquire into the issue.

plea.details: John Hares appealed John John and Richard Whitchurch for feloniously stealing four oxen. Richard Wolphyn was appealed for feloniously receiving, abetting, and harboring them.
procedural_notes: The King caused the appeal to come before him for determination and ordered the arrest of the accused.
Richard Wolphyn surrendered himself to the Marshalsea prison and was committed to the Marshal.

Richard Wolphyn pleaded a royal pardon by letters patent (dated 6 February, 36th Regnal Year) for all felonies and trespasses committed before 7 December, 36th Regnal Year, and produced a writ (dated 20 January, 39th Regnal Year) instructing him to find security for good behavior and not be molested by the justices.
He was discharged by the court.

plea.details: John Gorseley of Boldington, yeoman, on 9 August in the 39th year of the king's reign, at Boldington, with force and arms (swords, staffs, etc.) made an assault upon John Yery, servant of the Prior of Newnham, beat, wounded, and ill-treated him, by which the Prior lost the service of John Yery, to the damage of John Yery and the Prior. And that the said Gorseley on 1 June in the 38th year of the king's reign, with force and arms (swords, staffs, etc.) made an assault upon Richard Wayte at Goldington, and entered the Prior's warren and there hunted with his dogs, by virtue of which chase two hares worth 10s of the Prior's goods and chattels died, to the great damage of the Prior. And that the said John Gorseley with force and arms on 1 June in the 37th year of the king's reign, at Goldington in a pasture called Ravenesbregge, with force and arms (swords, staffs, etc.) made an assault upon John Chestre, servant of the Prior, beat and ill-treated him, by which the Prior lost the service of John Chestre, and chased 12 bullocks of the Prior's goods and chattels there and then, and against the King's peace.
procedural_notes: The King ordered the indictments to be brought before him for determination, and the sheriff was ordered to cause the defendant to appear.
At Westminster, John Gorseley appeared in person, pleaded not guilty, and put himself upon the country.
A jury was ordered to appear before the King on the quindene of Easter to recognize the truth.

plea.details: Indictment for felonies and trespasses, leading to outlawry, followed by royal pardon.
procedural_notes: Writ issued in the 35th regnal year for William Sondere and others to be exacted.
Sheriff returned that William Sondere and others were exacted at five county courts (held at Cheshunt) from 21 April, 35th regnal year, and were outlawed for non-appearance.
William Sondere brought into court before the King at Westminster in the 38th regnal year from custody of the Marshalsea.

William Sondere produces royal letters patent of pardon for all felonies, trespasses, offenses, and outlawry (dated 12 March, 38th regnal year), covering actions before 20 November, 38th regnal year, for which he was indicted, accused, or appealed.
William Sondere also produces a royal writ (dated 23 October, 39th regnal year) instructing justices not to molest him, provided he finds sufficient security for his good behavior in Chancery.
Court discharges William Sondere (goes without day).

plea.details: Richard John and William Raundele, constables of Sudbury, arrested John Bette of Melford on suspicion of felony and detained him. They then arranged for Walter Fraunceys and William Hede, constables of Melford, to receive John Bette, but the Melford constables refused to receive him.
procedural_notes: Presented by a jury of 12 before Henry Bourchier, steward of the liberty of Bury St Edmunds.
The King caused the indictment to be brought before him for termination.
A writ was issued to the sheriff to apprehend the defendants.
William Raundele appeared by Robert Dene, an attorney deemed insufficient in law.

plea.details: Robert Newman, having been arrested on suspicion of felony, failed to appear in the King's Court on his appointed day, as his pledges (Thomas Houghton and John Hall) had guaranteed his appearance. The pledges also failed to appear.
procedural_notes: Writ issued to the sheriff to capture Robert Newman, Thomas Houghton, and John Hall.
Sheriff returned that they were not found (non sunt inventi).
Writ of exigent ordered for Robert Newman, to be exacted from county to county until outlawed.

plea.details: Defendants were ordered to produce Joan Doge and Margaret Doge, who were indicted for felonies and trespasses, but failed to do so, incurring a redemption owed to the King.
procedural_notes: Warrant issued for the arrest of Richard Benton and Arnold Brocas to appear before the King, for their failure to produce Joan Doge and Margaret Doge in court.
Sheriffs returned that Joan Doge and Margaret Doge were not found (had not appeared).
New order issued for Joan Doge and Margaret Doge to be exacted from husting to husting until waived (outlawed), and to be apprehended for appearance before the King on the Octave of Saint Martin.

plea.details: Defendants are liable for the redemption of Richard Blenell, whom they mainprised but who failed to appear in court on a fixed day, as his pledges.
procedural_notes: Sheriffs returned that defendants were not found (non sunt inventi).
Order issued for defendants to be exacted from county to county until outlawed if not found.
New return date set for the Octave of Saint Martin.
Original failure to appear was set for the Octave of Saint Hilary.

plea.details: Action for a fine/redemption owed to the King by William Gylmyn and John Kelowe for failing to produce John Curteys, who was indicted for trespass.
procedural_notes: Writ issued to the sheriff for arrest; sheriff returned 'non est inventus' (not found).
Order for exigent ('exigi facias') from county to county until outlawed.

plea.details: For various trespasses, contempts, insurrections, resistances, and other offenses
procedural_notes: Initial order for sheriff to arrest defendants for failing to appear.

New return date: Octave of Saint Michael.

plea.details: concerning certain trespasses and insurrections
procedural_notes: Initial order to the sheriff to take the defendants.

Order to the sheriff to cause them to be exacted from county to county until they are outlawed.

plea.details: Indicted for certain trespasses.

Defendants were commanded to appear before the King in the Octave of St. Hilary.

plea.details: Writ of capias issued for arrest of individuals.
procedural_notes: Writ issued to sheriff to take named individuals.

plea.details: Recognizance for keeping the King's peace, specifically regarding John Kembell, which was forfeited due to the principal defendant, Nicholas Basset, failing to appear. The King seeks execution of the bonds.
procedural_notes: Nicholas Basset was in Marshalsea prison.
Nicholas Basset and his sureties (Richard Basset, Richard Bulke, William William) entered into a recognizance to keep the peace, particularly towards John Kembell.
Nicholas Basset's bond was 20 pounds, and each surety's bond was 10 pounds.
Nicholas Basset failed to appear in court as required.
The King (Edward IV, first year of reign) is to execute the forfeiture against Nicholas Basset for 20 pounds and against each surety for 10 pounds.

defendants.status_note: Party producing letters patent in court; matters pending in execution.

Matters pending in execution

plea.details: against William Broup for trespass.
procedural_notes: The Lord King, by his attorney Thomas Clerk, appeared on the fourth day against William Broup concerning a plea of trespass.
William Broup did not appear.
The sheriff was commanded repeatedly to arrest him but returned that he was not found.
Therefore, the sheriff is commanded again to arrest him and have his body before the King on the quindene of Easter.

plea.details: John Soper, captured on suspicion of felony, failed to appear in court as required, and his pledges also failed to produce him.
procedural_notes: Writ issued for arrest; Sheriff returned that the defendants were not found.

plea.details: For a redemption (fine) owed to the King due to Robert Baker's conviction for trespass committed with force and arms against Robert William, merchant, and against the King's peace.
procedural_notes: Command issued to the sheriff to arrest Robert Baker, returnable on the Octave of Saint Hilary.
Robert Baker, having been convicted by a jury, did not appear.
The sheriff returned that Robert Baker was not found.
An exigent process for outlawry was initiated against Robert Baker, returnable on the Octave of Saint Michael.

plea.details: The defendants are ordered to satisfy the King for his redemption because John Tebbe, taken on suspicion of felony, failed to appear in the King's Court on the appointed day, and his pledges who guaranteed his appearance also failed to come.
procedural_notes: An order was issued to the sheriff to arrest John Tebbe, Robert Cosfe, and Thomas Benfeld to ensure their appearance before the King on the Octave of St. Hilary.
The sheriff reported that the defendants were not found.
Consequently, the sheriff is ordered to exact them from county to county until they are outlawed.
They are now ordered to appear before the King on the Octave of St. Michael.

defendants.status_note: Previously convicted by jury; failed to appear; sheriff reported not found; subject to outlawry process.

plea.details: Payment to the King for a trespass with force and arms committed against John Cleyne, esquire, merchant, for which Robert Broker was previously convicted by a jury.

plea.details: Indictment for rebellion, levying war against the King (treason), felonies, and other misdeeds, against the King's peace and seeking the destruction of the King's crown and regalia.
procedural_notes: Indictment was brought before the King's court for termination.
Defendant Regnald Andrewe appeared in person and surrendered himself to the Marshalsea prison.

Defendant presented letters patent from the King, granting pardon, remission, and release for all treasons, felonies, transgressions, and other misdeeds committed by him before July 18, in the 31st year of the King's reign, and granting him the King's firm peace.

Defendant also presented a writ from the King, dated July 18, regnal year 31, directing the justices not to molest or aggrieve him, provided he finds sufficient security in Chancery for his good behavior towards the King and all his people, according to the statute.
Defendant requested to be dismissed by the court.
It was decided by the court that the defendant should go without day (case dismissed).

plea.details: Recognizance for good behavior (surety of the peace) by John Thomson, undertaking not to harm John Leylond or disturb the King's peace, by ambush, assaults, or any other way, under penalty of 20 pounds.
procedural_notes: Richard Hille of the parish of St Mary Matfelon without Aldgate, London, Middlesex (Brewer), Regnald Frent of the same parish and county (Brewer), John Morth of the same parish and county (Goldsmith), and William Novyny of the same parish and county (Graser) stood as sureties, each bound for 10 pounds.
The sums are recognized to be owed to the King and leviable from their lands and chattels if John Thomson defaults on his undertaking and is lawfully convicted.

plea.details: regarding the principal act of the death of Thomas Burton, Gentleman, brother of the said Robert
procedural_notes: Jurors to recognize upon their oath if the aforesaid William is guilty of the principal act of the death of Thomas Burton, Gentleman, brother of the said Robert, whereof he is appealed, or not.
Put in respite before the Lord King until three weeks from Easter, wherever, etc.

Unless the beloved and faithful William Yelverton, one of the King's Justices assigned to hold pleas before the King himself, comes first on Thursday next after the Feast of the Annunciation of the Blessed Virgin Mary at Norwich, according to the form of the statute, etc.
By default of the jurors, and the sheriff is to have the bodies, etc.
The same day is given to the aforesaid parties, etc., namely to the aforesaid William by his mainprise as before, etc.

And it is to be known by the King's writ afterwards, namely the 7th day of February in this same term, delivered before the Lord King at Westminster to Robert Culpeper, deputy sheriff of the aforesaid county, to be executed according to the form of the law, with the peril incumbent, etc.

plea.details: a certain trespass inflicted on Edmund Grey by the said William Walshefe together with Reginald Conyne, William Alrede, John Aneden, John Shellyng, John William Horwode, and Robert Olyve.

William Walshefe did not come.
It was commanded to the sheriff as before that he distrain him.
The sheriff returned that he is distrained, whence issues 10 shillings; he is mainprised by the pledge of William Code and Richard Solley.
It is commanded to the sheriff as many times that he distrain him by all lands and that of the issues and that he have his body before the lord King on the quindene of Easter wherever.

plea.details: The defendant with force and arms (swords, staves) broke the close of William Spencer at Poplar in the said county and took and led away Richard Carter, William Spencer's servant, who was in his service there. This caused William Spencer to lose the service of his servant from December 10, 39 Henry VI until the Octave of Hilary next following. This was against the King's peace.
procedural_notes: Action brought by bill.
Defendant sought a day to imparl.
Day given to the parties before the King at Westminster until the Wednesday next after 15 days from Easter for the defendant to imparl and then to respond.

plea.details: Defendant took and carried away with force and arms a pyx belonging to the plaintiff, containing charters, writings, and other muniments, at Westminster, to the great damage of the plaintiff and against the King's peace.

Writ of exigents issued for outlawry, to appear before the King in the Octave of St. John the Baptist.

plea.details: Action based on an 8 Henry VI statute. The defendants falsely and maliciously procured an indictment against William Derlyngton for violently assaulting and feloniously raping Margaret Michell in Middlesex. Derlyngton was acquitted after incurring significant expenses and labor. The plaintiff claims 100 pounds in damages and sues according to the statute, which allows triple damages against procurers of false indictments.
procedural_notes: Plaintiff sues qui tam for the King and himself.
Plaintiff appeared in his own person.
The original indictment against the plaintiff was procured while he was residing in London, not Middlesex, the county where the indictment was taken.
Plaintiff was duly acquitted by a jury.

plea.details: On account of a certain assize of novel disseisin of Thomas Bossey concerning two messuages with appurtenances in Tewkesbury, done with force and arms and against the peace of the present King, concerning which he was convicted by the recognition of a certain assize of novel disseisin taken between them.
procedural_notes: It was commanded to the sheriff that he cause Edmund Draper to be exacted from county to county until he is outlawed if he does not appear, etc. And then let him take him and cause him to be safely kept, etc., so that he may have his body before the lord King on this day, namely, in the Octave of Saint Hilary wherever, etc.

And he did not come, and the sheriff did not send the writ concerning it. It is commanded to the sheriff that he cause him to be exacted anew from county to county until he is outlawed if he does not appear, etc. And then let him take him and safely, etc., so that he may have his body before the lord King in the Octave of Saint Michael wherever, etc.

plea.details: John Kynge owes redemption to the King for failing to prosecute his writ of appeal against Simon Hoge, formerly of Eryilond, milward, and William Clyve, formerly of Exeter, weynmaker, and others, for robbery committed against John Kynge and breach of the King's peace. The appeal was initiated in the King's Court before the King.
procedural_notes: Initial order issued to the sheriff to exact John Kynge from county to county until he is outlawed if he does not appear, and then to arrest him, to have his body before the King on the Octave of Hilary.
The defendants in Kynge's original appeal (Simon Hoge and William Clyve) did not appear, and the sheriff did not send the writ.

New order issued to the sheriff to exact John Kynge anew from county to county until he is outlawed if he does not appear, and then to arrest him, to have his body before the King on the Octave of Michael.

plea.details: Indictment by jury for multiple offenses. Firstly, felonious housebreaking and theft of a horse (value 40s), a saddle, a bridle, two iron helmets (sallet), eight yards of fustian cloth, two bows, sixty arrows, a 'Glexe' staff, and a 'Wodeknyf' knife (total value 40s) from William Castard's house at Little Munden, Hertfordshire. Secondly, forcible entry with force and arms and a strong hand into the manor of William and Elizabeth Castard in Little Munden, expelling and disseizing them, and holding them out against the Statute of Forcible Entry, with approximately 32 other unknown malefactors. Thirdly, assault, battery, wounding, imprisonment, and ill-treatment of William and Elizabeth Castard, Ralph John, William John, John Kempe, John Castard, William Castard, John Bernard, and William Radeclyff at Little Munden against the King's peace.
procedural_notes: Case initiated by presentment of a 12-person jury before Justices of the Peace in Hertfordshire.

plea.details: A presentment was made by 12 jurors that John Lobenham, William Staldewell, John Bussh, William Saldewell, and 40 unknown accomplices, did unlawfully assemble and arm themselves in a warlike manner, riding in illicit routs, terrifying the King's lieges. They assaulted John Wale and William Wale at Sprotton, threatening them to the point they despaired of their lives. They then forcibly entered John Wale's cultivated land, trampled his rye, and feloniously took and carried away four wagonloads of rye (worth 20 shillings). They detained the grain and resisted the King's bailiff, Thomas Shyres, and later the undersheriff, Robert Olney, who attempted to replevy the grain, by threats of death and rescue. The defendants then threshed the grain by night and feloniously carried it out of the county, in a conspiracy to maintain their wrongdoing and subvert the King's laws.
procedural_notes: Presentment made on Friday, September 14, 1459, before William Lucy, Knight, and Robert Tanfeld, Justices of the King's Peace.

plea.details: Accusation of robbery and death.
procedural_notes: Case remained sine die (without a day) due to the change of reign from Henry VI (de facto king) to Edward IV (now king by right and heir to Henry IV and Richard II). The case later resumed in the first year of Edward IV's reign.

John Wale, the initial appellant, failed to appear on the fourth day of plea; he was ordered to be arrested. His mainpernors (William Ashby of Abthorpe, Gentleman; John Frankton of Abthorpe, Gentleman; John Horne of Daventry, Gentleman; and John Frankton of Harleston, Gentleman) were in mercy for not producing his body.
Defendants John Lobenham, Guillim Saldewell, John Bussh, and William Saldewell were committed to the Marshalsea.
Regarding the King's suit, the defendants, being pressed on the attaint, separately pleaded not guilty and put themselves on the country.
A jury was summoned but was put in respite multiple times due to the absence of jurors.

Eventually, the jury found the defendants (John Lobenham, Guillim Saldewell, John Bussh, and William Saldewell) not guilty of the premises, nor was any of them guilty of robbery and death of the within-named persons.

Damages sustained by occasion of the appeal were assessed for the defendants: John Lobenham (10 shillings), Thomas Saldewell (10 shillings), John Bussh (damages not specified), and William Saldewell (4 shillings).
Therefore, John Lobenham, Thomas Saldewell, John Bussh, and William Saldewell were acquitted of the said suit and felony.

plea.details: contempt and trespass against the form of the statute lately issued concerning servants.
procedural_notes: Defendant failed to appear on the fourth day.
Sheriff ordered to attach defendant; returned that defendant was not found.
Capias ordered for defendant's body to appear before the King on the Octave of the Purification of Blessed Mary.

plea.details: The defendants, along with John Aleyn, John Colman, and Richard Caryoll, forcibly broke the closes and houses of the plaintiffs at Redenhale and Aldbergh, and assaulted, beat, wounded, and ill-treated Katherine Bawedy, their servant, threatening her life and mutilation, thereby causing her to be unable to attend to the plaintiffs' business and leading the plaintiffs to lose her service, all against the King's peace.
procedural_notes: A writ of capias was issued repeatedly; the sheriff returned that the defendants were not found.

Therefore, a writ of exigent is ordered for them to be proclaimed from county to county until outlawed if they do not appear, and then to be arrested and brought before the King in the Octave of St. John the Baptist.

plea.details: The defendants, with force and arms, made an assault upon Thomas Collys at Stoke Holy Cross, and beat, wounded, and ill-treated him.
procedural_notes: Plaintiff Thomas Collys senior appeared by his attorney John Peye.
Defendants John Buntyng and Robert Buk did not appear.
The sheriff was repeatedly ordered to arrest them.
The sheriff returned that the defendants were not found.

Therefore, an order was issued to the sheriff to cause the defendants to be exacted from county to county until they are outlawed, or to arrest them and have their bodies before the King on the Octave of Saint John the Baptist.
Defendant did not appear.
Warrant issued for arrest (capias).
Sheriff returned non est inventus.
Alias capias issued.
To appear before the King in Octave of Purification of Blessed Mary.

plea.details: Plaintiff seeks execution for debt and damages against defendant Thomas Hurst.
procedural_notes: Defendant summoned by scire facias but failed to appear.
Plaintiff granted execution against defendant for the debt and damages.

plea.details: Defendant, William Wynsham (also known as William Marshall), on the sixteenth day of December in the thirty-seventh year of the current King's reign, with force and arms (namely, swords and staves), took and led away Thomas Thurston, apprentice of the plaintiff Ralph Marche, from Ralph's service in the parish of St. Giles without Cripplegate in Cripplegate Ward, London. As a result, Ralph lost his apprentice's service from the aforementioned sixteenth day of December until the sixth day of November next following, suffering other wrongs, to his damage of forty pounds, and against the King's peace.
procedural_notes: Defendant requested a day to imparl, which was granted.
Defendant defaulted on appearance at the appointed day.
Plaintiff requested judgment and damages due to defendant's default and lack of response.
A writ of inquiry of damages was issued to the sheriffs of London to assess the plaintiff's damages, to be returned on the Wednesday after three weeks of Easter.
Defendants did not appear.
Writ of capias sicut pluries issued for their arrest.
Sheriff returned non est inventus.
Further writ of capias sicut prius issued for their appearance before the King in Octave of Purification of Blessed Mary.

Defendants did not appear.

Writ of capias alias issued to the sheriff, returnable on the quindene of Easter.

plea.details: Of a plea of trespass.
procedural_notes: Defendant did not appear on the fourth day.
A writ was issued to the sheriffs to arrest the defendant, and they returned that he was not found.
Therefore, as previously commanded, an alias writ is issued to the sheriffs to arrest him and bring his body before the Lord King on the Octave of the Purification of Blessed Mary.

plea.details: He made an assault with force and arms upon John at Walden, and beat, wounded, and ill-treated him, and other wrongs, to his grave damage and against the peace.
procedural_notes: The defendant did not appear.
A command was issued to the sheriffs, as often, to take him.
The sheriffs returned that he was not found.
Therefore, a command is issued to the sheriffs to cause him to be exacted from county to county until he is outlawed.
The King's writ was delivered to John Seton, deputy of the sheriffs, on February 4th in the same term at Westminster, to be executed.
Defendants did not appear.
Sheriff returned that John Saynesbury was distrained, whence issues of 10 pence, mainperned by Richard Hert and John Blontpayn.
Pledges Richard Hert and John Blontpayn are in mercy.
Sheriff ordered to distrain John Saynesbury by all lands and have his body before the King on the quindene of Easter.
Sheriff returned that John Hymerford has nothing.
Sheriff ordered to take John Hymerford and have his body before the King at the same term.

Sheriff ordered to distrain them.

Defendants are in mercy (fined).
Sheriff ordered to distrain Saynesbury by all lands and have his body before the King in 15 days from Easter.
Sheriff returned John Hymerford had no goods (nihil habet).
Sheriff ordered to arrest John Hymerford and have his body before the King at the same term.
Defendants did not appear.
Sheriff ordered to distrain Peter Bamfeld and take John Miryman.
Sheriff returned that Peter Bamfeld was distrained, with issues of 10d.

Sheriff ordered to distrain Peter Bamfeld by all lands and have his body before the King 15 days from Easter.

defendants.relationship_description: those who wickedly divert forfeited goods and deodands from royal alms

plea.details: Royal Letters Patent granting the King's Almoner, Henry Seuer, the right to inquire, seize, and collect all deodands and goods and chattels forfeited by persons killing themselves within the realm of England, and to distribute them as alms.
procedural_notes: Letters patent presented in court and sought to be enrolled.
Royal writ directed to Justices for pleas also presented.

plea.details: Plaintiff David Smalcombe recovered 53 shillings 4 pence in debt and 3 shillings 4 pence in damages against defendant Thomas Hurst in the Bristol Guildhall Court. Plaintiff now seeks execution of this judgment in the King's Bench.
procedural_notes: Original judgment was obtained by a jury verdict in the Bristol Guildhall Court.
A writ of scire facias was issued from the King's Bench commanding the defendant to show cause why the plaintiff should not have execution of the judgment.
The defendant was warned (premonitus) to appear but failed to do so on the fourth day of the plea.
Execution for the debt and damages was granted to the plaintiff due to the defendant's non-appearance.

plea.details: William Wynsham alias Marchall, with force and arms (swords, staffs, etc.) on 16 December in the 37th year of the King's reign, took and led away Thomas Thurston, apprentice of Ralph Marche, while he was in Ralph's service in the parish of St Giles without Cripplegate in the Ward of Cripplegate, London. As a result, Ralph lost the service of his apprentice from the said 16 December until 24 November next following, to his damage of 40 pounds, and against the King's peace.
procedural_notes: Pledges to prosecute: John Doo and Richard Roo.

plea.details: of various felonies
procedural_notes: Capias writ issued to Sheriff of Hertford for capture.
Defendants ordered to appear before the King on the morrow of the Purification of Blessed Mary.
Defendants did not appear, and Sheriff returned 'not found'.
Proclamations made at two Hertford County Courts (Dec 25, 39th year of King; Jan 22, same year) for defendants to appear.
Order for exigent (outlawry) from county court to county court until outlawed, then capture and appearance before the King in the Octave of St. Michael.

plea.details: for various felonies and trespasses
procedural_notes: Precept issued to the sheriff of Essex to arrest Thomas Hall and Richard Appleton, or proclaim their appearance, to answer the King for various felonies and trespasses for which they were indicted in Suffolk.
The defendants did not appear.
The sheriff of Essex returned that they were not found, and proclaimed them at two county courts held at Chelmsford (on Tuesday, 9 December, 39 Henry VI, and on Tuesday, 6 January, 39 Henry VI).
Precept then issued to the sheriff of Suffolk to exact them from county to county until they are outlawed, or to arrest them for appearance before the King in the Octave of St. Michael.

plea.details: Of certain felonies and trespasses
procedural_notes: Precept issued to the Sheriff of Sussex to arrest Henry Bysshop and have him appear before the King on the morrow of the Purification of Blessed Mary.
It is noted that Henry Bysshop was indicted in Middlesex.
If Henry could not be found in Sussex, he was to be proclaimed at two county courts.

The Sheriff of Sussex returned that Henry was not found, and that he had been proclaimed at the county court in Chichester on Thursday, 18 December (39th year of the King's reign) and again on Thursday, 15 January (same year).

Precept issued to the Sheriff of Middlesex to cause Henry to be exacted from county court to county court until he is outlawed, and to have his body before the King on the Octave of St. John the Baptist.

plea.details: Concerning certain trespasses and rescues, whereof they are accused by the petition of Simon Mountford, knight, late sheriff of the aforesaid county.
procedural_notes: They did not appear.
It is returned that they are not found.
The sheriff is ordered to cause them to be exacted from county to county until they are outlawed.

plea.details: of certain trespasses
procedural_notes: A summons was issued to the sheriff to bring John Gaywode before the Lord King on the morrow of the Purification of the Blessed Mary.
John Gaywode did not appear.
The sheriff returned that he had nothing (i.e., could not find him or property to seize).
Therefore, an order (capias) was issued to the sheriff to arrest John Gaywode and bring him before the Lord King in fifteen days from Easter.

defendants.status_note: subject to outlawry and arrest due to non-appearance and not found by sheriff

plea.details: The defendants, with force and arms (swords, staves, etc.), on the 12th day of December in the 38th year of the current King's reign, took and carried away goods and chattels belonging to William Est at Bermondsey, valued at twenty pounds, including a silver-gilt paten with cover, a cloth of gold, a silver-gilt mirror, a cup called a Serpentine, a silk belt with silver-gilt harness, a silver folding spoon, a psalter, a primer, two pairs of prayer beads (one coral with silver-gilt gauds, one Carneau with an agate stone and ring), an image of St. James made of mother-of-pearl with silver-gilt (hanging from the beads), a shirt, a bow, two sheaves of arrows, and a hand sword, causing forty marks in damages, against the King's peace.
procedural_notes: Defendant John Amyas pleads not guilty and puts himself on the country (jury).
Jury summoned for 15 days from Easter.
Plaintiff William Est appeared; defendant William Styward did not.
A writ was issued to the sheriff to arrest William Styward, but the sheriff returned 'not found'.
An 'alias' writ was issued for William Styward's arrest.

plea.details: Plaintiff appeared in person against the defendant concerning the aforesaid plea, and the defendant did not appear.
procedural_notes: Order was given to the sheriff to arrest the defendant.
The sheriff returned that the defendant was not found.
Therefore, as before, the sheriff is ordered to arrest him and bring his body before the Lord King at the aforesaid term.

plea.details: King seeks to levy fines against William Daynecourt and his sureties (John Santon and William Parchomener) for breach of a peace bond. Daynecourt, previously in Marshalsea prison, was released on recognizance (bail) to keep the peace, especially towards Alice Porons. He allegedly breached this bond by assaulting Johanna Payn, taking 10 marks from her, and by taking two silver-bound murras from John Scotte, all 'vi et armis'. Daynecourt and his sureties had acknowledged debts of 40 pounds (Daynecourt) and 20 pounds (each surety) to the King if the peace was broken.
procedural_notes: William Daynecourt was released from Marshalsea prison on bail ('in ballivum') under recognizance.
John Santon and William Parchomener stood as sureties for Daynecourt.
Bail conditions included personal appearance and keeping the peace, especially towards Alice Porons, specifically not to cause harm by ambush or assault.
Sureties bound for 20 pounds each, Daynecourt for 40 pounds, payable to the King upon conviction of breach.
King received information that Daynecourt violated peace by assaulting Johanna Payn 'vi et armis' in Hackney, Middlesex, and taking 10 marks from her.
Daynecourt also allegedly took two silver-bound murras from John Scotte 'vi et armis' in Shoreditch, Middlesex.
King issued writ ('scire facias') to Sheriffs of London to notify Daynecourt, Santon, and Parchomener to show why the fines should not be levied.
Sheriffs returned the writ, stating they notified the parties.
Defendants (Daynecourt, Santon, Parchomener) appeared by their attorney, John Boll.
Defendants pleaded not guilty to acts 'vi et armis' and general trespass, except for the taking of the two murras.
Regarding the murras, defendants claimed John Scotte licensed Daynecourt to take them in London.
The King's prosecutor, William Crexton, denied the license.
Issue joined; jury to inquire separately for Middlesex and London.

plea.details: Defendants, as pledges, failed to produce David Taillour, who was indicted for various felonies, murders, and trespasses, resulting in their obligation for redemption to the King.
procedural_notes: Writ issued to the sheriff to apprehend the defendants for their failure to produce David Taillour.
Sheriff returned that the defendants were not found.
Writ of exigent issued for the defendants to be exacted from county to county until outlawed.

plea.details: Accused by return of Edmund Montford, knight, late sheriff of the aforesaid county, for certain trespasses and rescues.
procedural_notes: Order was given to the sheriff that he not omit etc. but attach Thomas Baldewyn, William Dndell, John Bromley & John Taillour so that he might have them before the lord King on this day, namely in the Octaves of Saint Hilary, wherever etc. to answer the lord King concerning certain trespasses and rescues.
And they did not come.
And the sheriff returned that they were not found.

Order is given to the sheriff that he not omit etc. but take them if etc. and safely etc. so that he may have their bodies before the lord King in the Octaves of the Purification of Blessed Mary wherever etc.

plea.details: divers felonies and trespasses
procedural_notes: Writ issued to Sheriff of Warwick to apprehend defendants.
Defendants are indicted in Staffordshire.
Sheriff of Warwick returned that proclamations were made for defendants to appear.
Exigent writ issued to Sheriff of Staffordshire to exact defendants until outlawry.

plea.details: for failing to produce Thomas Flete, Grocer, as they had pledged, to answer John Bilyngton for a plea of trespass.
procedural_notes: Sheriff commanded to take the defendants
Defendants failed to appear
Sheriff returned that defendants were not found
Sheriff commanded to exact them from county to county until outlawed

plea.details: For failing to appear in the King's Court to answer the King for certain trespasses, contempts, and rescues, for which he was accused by the sheriff's return.
procedural_notes: Precept issued to the sheriff to arrest defendants to appear before the King in the Octave of Saint Hilary.
Robert Ralegh failed to appear, despite being bailed by pledges, and the pledges also failed to appear.
The sheriff returned that the defendants were not found.

New precept issued to the sheriff to cause the defendants to be proclaimed for outlawry from county to county until they are outlawed, and then to arrest them to appear before the King in the Octave of Saint Michael.
Writ of Precept with non-omittas clause issued to the sheriff, returnable in Hilary Term before the King's Bench (ubicunque).

plea.details: Making, fabrication, pronouncement, publication, and reading of false deeds, causing disturbance and vexation to the plaintiffs, in contempt of the King and against the form of a statute.
procedural_notes: Defendant granted license to imparl.
Defendant pleaded not guilty and put himself on the country.
Case remained without day ('sine die') due to the change in monarchy (King Edward IV succeeding King Henry VI from 'de facto' King Henry VI).
Plaintiffs requested a new writ for re-attachment of the defendant and summoning a jury.
Defendant failed to appear when solemnly exacted.
Jury taken against the defendant by default.
Sheriff commanded to distrain jurors.
Jury found the defendant guilty.
Damages assessed by jury at 100 shillings for principal damages and 20 shillings for costs.
Court increased damages by 6 shillings and 8 pence for costs.
Total damages awarded to plaintiffs: 6 pounds, 6 shillings, and 8 pence.
Defendant was ordered to be taken ('capiatur').
Defendant committed to the Marshal for damages until satisfied.
Plaintiffs acknowledged satisfaction of damages by the defendant.
Defendant was discharged and allowed to go without day.

plea.details: John Laske, with force and arms (swords, staves, etc.), on 12 September in the 39th year of the current King's reign, took and carried away forty quarters of lime belonging to John Morteyne, found at Retherhithe, valued at 40 shillings, against the King's peace.
procedural_notes: Defendant (John Laske) appeared in person and sought a day to imparl, which was granted.
A day is given to the parties before the King until 15 days from Easter, wherever the King might be, for the defendant to imparl and then to respond.
Defendant (John Laske) was mainprised by William Serle of London, yeoman, and Henry Stone of London, skinner, to appear before the King at the specified term.

plea.details: Walter Bury and John Saverey, with force and arms (swords, staves, etc.), broke the closes of Nicholas Kynghton and Thomas Facy at Durerste and Kentysbeare. They also, with certain animals (horses, oxen, cows, pigs, and sheep), depastured, trampled, and consumed their grass recently growing at Durerste, to the value of 100 shillings. This trespass of depasturing, trampling, and consuming the grass continued from the Thursday next after the feast of Saints Peter and Paul in the 37th year of the present King's reign up to the third day of January in the 38th year of the King's reign (the day of the original writ's impetration), to the grave damage of the plaintiffs and against the King's peace.
procedural_notes: Plaintiffs Nicholas Kynghton and Thomas Facy appeared by their attorney, Richard Louermor, and made their complaint.
Defendants Walter Bury and John Saverey appeared by their attorney, John Hopyng, and defended the force and injury.
Defendants sought leave to imparl, which was granted.
A day is given to the parties before the King, fifteen days from Easter, wherever the King might be, specifically for Walter and John to imparl and then to respond.

plea.details: To satisfy the Lord King concerning his redemption, by occasion of a certain trespass done with force and arms to Richard Fowy and against the peace of the Lord King, for which he was convicted by a jury of the country.
procedural_notes: Issues from Cornwall.
The defendant was ordered to have his body before the Lord King on the Octave of St Hilary.
The defendant did not come.
The sheriff returned that the defendant is distrained, hence issues.
Mainpernors John Broun and John Best are in mercy.
As before, the sheriff is ordered to not omit but distrain him by all lands etc. and that of the issues etc., and that he have his body before the Lord King fifteen days from Easter wherever etc.

plea.details: concerning certain articles presented against them

Mainpernors John Baron and William Downe are in mercy.
Sheriff again ordered to distrain the vill by all lands and issues to appear before the King in 15 days from Easter Day.

Mainpernors Thomas Pye and William Hon are in mercy.

plea.details: Thomas Standrorp, gaoler of the King's Gaol of Raleigh, was commanded to produce the body of Robert Hughes, detained for suspicion of felony, before the King on the octave of St. Hilary, but he failed to appear.
procedural_notes: The gaoler was distrained, and 10 pence in issues were collected.
The gaoler and his mainpernors, Richard Hert and John Broo, were amerced.
A new command was issued to distrain the gaoler and produce Robert Hughes on the quindene of Easter.

John Hynde did not appear; he was distrained, and his mainpernors (John Baron and Nicholas Dese) are in mercy.
A further writ was issued to distrain Hynde again to produce the defendants by the quindene of Easter.

plea.details: trespass and forcible entry
procedural_notes: Writ issued to the sheriff to distrain William Reynold.
Defendant did not appear.
Sheriff returned that defendant was distrained, with issues of 10 pence.
Pledges Richard Brown and David Voo were in mercy (fined).
New writ issued to the sheriff to distrain defendant by all lands and have his body before the King 15 days after Easter.

plea.details: Assault upon Thomas Bekeley at Saint George's Field in the parish of Saint George in Southwark, where he was beaten, wounded, and ill-treated, and feloniously robbed of a purse with four marks in cash, a gold ring worth five shillings, and a silver ring worth twelve pence.
procedural_notes: The King caused this indictment to be brought before him.
Defendant John Getty surrendered to Marshalsea prison and pleaded not guilty.
Bail was granted to John Miller of Orpington, Kent, Gentleman, and Robert Wode of Eastwell, Kent, Gentleman.
